text: A gaping hole in the concrete side of a freeway. On the embankment beside the hole BRENDAN FRYE squats, shoulders hunched. His dark eyes behind thin glasses watch the shallow stream of water which flows into the tunnel.
not more than six inches deep. Just beneath the surface a young woman's pale blue arm in gaudy bracelets bats again the edge of her body like a docked boat. A pebble plinks into the water beside it.1

A single locker. That same arm, bracelets and all, slips note through the slats, then leaves quickly. As the cage empties a lone figure slumps to the locker. Opens it. The note falls to his feet. The figure is Brendan. He unfolds the note (folded in a triangle) -- "12:30 PICO & ALEXANDER".
Pico and Alexander.2
12:43.   Brendan looks up from the watch.

He sits on the curb of a wide suburban street, eats lunch from a brown bag and watches a phone booth on the corner. shows no surprise when it begins to ring. Brendan goes to the phone and puts the receiver to his ear. Silence for a moment, then a thin female voice from the phone. 1 Originally Dode was later revealed to have been hiding ab 2 The street names were changed in production to match exis afford to create custom street signs.)
(over phone) Brendan?
Emily?
(weakly) Yeah. How's things?
(slow, deliberate) Status quo.
Yeah?
Uh huh.
That's good.
Her voice thins to a high, strained breath. She is crying
What's going on, Em?
(through strained crying) It's good to see you, Brendan.
Brendan's eyes glance around the surrounding street. Emil is crying again. EMILY (CONT'D) (cont'd) It's been some time.
Two months.
Yeah. I didn't even know your locker. I had to ask Brain.
More crying noises.
Em, why don't we meet somewhere?
I can't.
Why not?
I screwed up real bad. I really screwed up.
Screwed up how?
(blubbering, fast and incoherent) I did what she said with the brick, I didn't know it was bad, but the pin's on it now for poor Frisco and they're playing it all on me-
Slow down now, what?
You gotta help me Brendan I think tug- Oh!

With a sharp breath the line clicks dead just as a black mustang roars by. Brendan drops the receiver and spins ou of the booth. There, another pay phone up the hill -- empty. Brendan turns to the black mustang, far down the street. man's hand drops a cigarette butt from the driver side window.1 The mustang turns the corner, gone. Brendan walks after it, finds the cigarette butt on the street. Still smoking. A pale blue arrow is printed on the filter. In the distance the class bell rings.

The high school is open air - the hallways are alleyways between buildings. A short kid with eyeglasses the size o 1 Because of the orientation of the street, this was all fl hand came from the passenger window. The dialogue in the changed to match, causing mass confusion for about half a Volkswagen headlights sits against the wall. Brendan ente leans on the wall beside him.
Brain.
Hey Brendan. It's been awhile. Where you been eating?
Back of school.
Huh. Yeah, no one's seen you. What's it been, a couple months?
Yeah, it's been awhile. You gave Emily my locker number?
A few days ago. Was I wrong?
What?
To give it?
No.
It's been so long, I don't know you two's stats.
It has been awhile.   Who's she been eating with?
(uncomfortable) I dunno. It's hard to keep track.
Is it?
(shrugs) Can be.
The Brain avoids Brendan's gaze.
Uh huh.
A beat.
She hasn't been doing too good.
Yeah well. I'm not looking for a patch up. Em's life is her own. But she asked for my help.
Help with what?
I don't know. I don't even care, it's not my business. I just want to know she's ok, so I've got to find her. That's all this is.
Well. I know she was poking in with the Ivy-bound cheerleading elite. Laura Dannon's crowd.
Across the parking lot a beautiful girl with dark long ha kisses an football player.
Laura Dannon there with the Rabbit?
Yeah. Brad Bramish with her. Cream on the upper crust.
Brad laughs heartily.
(softly) He's a sap.
Know him?
By sight.

I won't argue then. Anyway Em tagged after them for a bit, but it didn't work. So she picked her way down the food chain. Last I seen she was with whasshername, that drama vamp. Small time dealer, augh, the evil one, the one you dated-
Kara.
That's my bus.
You know her locker number?
Kara's?
Em's.
Thanks Brain. Keep your specs on, find me if she shows.
Sure.
The Brain trots off. In the distance Brad and Laura laugh and he kisses her. Her hair blows in the wind.
Empty. Locker 239 is open, its door swinging gently in th wind.

Brendan sits against the massive building, flipping throu loose papers. He finds two photographs, one of Emily hugg him, the other of Emily with a beautiful sharp-eyed girl a party, drinks in hand. Sorting more papers, he finds a red card with a sequined mask on the front. The bottom edge has been torn off.
Sixth period has broke. Masses of students pile into buss
A huge chunk of brown building. Brendan strides towards i

Drama people sit on the floor facing the stage. Brendan steps behind one, the sharp-eyed girl from the picture. S holds a freshman boy's head in her lap. Pets it like a do She looks back at Brendan, her face in shadow.
(through a mocking smile) Hello, Brendan.
Kara.
Come to see the show?
Kisses the freshman's forehead, purring.
No, I didn't. (nudges the freshman with his toe) Lapdog, blow.
The freshman sits up, looks to Kara like a spooked puppy.
(to the lapdog) Stay. (to Brendan) Don't be mean.
I'm all friendly. (to the lapdog) Watch your head, kid - that thing bites.
The dog pops up again. Kara pulls him down and nuzzles hi ear. BRENDAN (CONT'D) (cont'd) I need words.
I'm listening.
About Emily Kostich.
She stops nuzzling a little too quickly.
(to the dog) Get me my purse. (he goes) Hurry!
He breaks into a trot. Kara smiles at Brendan.
Still picking your teeth with freshmen?
You were a freshman once.
She slides her fingers up his arm. He growls and pushes t away.
Way once, sister. You and Em were tight for a bit. Who's she eating with now?
Eating with?
Eating with. Lunch.           Who.
You're a cutie.
You gonna tell me?
Guess you're up from the underneath then. The whole Jerr thing blown over. Lucky strikes, you and your partner get bulled, you come up clean. But I guess you were always the brains of the outfit.1

1 One of many instances of an allusion to the Jerr backstor trimmed back in the editing process for clarity. The auth a stand alone short story, but probably never will, so in Emily were still an item she started hanging out with Jer didn't approve, so he partnered up with Jerr then ratted found out, and that led to their breakup on the field, wh
Where's Emily?
Sometimes I wonder why I dumped you.
(standing to go) God.
I don't know where she's at, Brendan.
I know you do, so why don't you want me to find her?
Maybe I'm looking out for you.
(going) Well I appreciate that.
Brendan... you looking to get back into things? I could use you.
He is gone.   Behind Kara, the play goes on.
The play is seen in shadow-play through the backdrop. Brendan slips in through an exit door, crosses the backst area and enters the dressing rooms.

Cramped and empty. Pictures of Kara with friends are stuc in the mirror. Brendan roughly searches drawers, bags, pockets... nothing. He stops. A red edge behind one of th photos - the same red card with a mask on it, but whole. Across the bottom in small print: "Halloween in January - Call for DETAILS - 555-2394"
Brendan pulls a phone across his desk and dials the numbe on the flyer.
(over phone) Hello?
Brendan hesitates.
Hello, ma'am, this is Tom, I'm a friend from school. Could I speak to...
He trails off.
(over phone) Oh, hi Tom. Laura's here, hold on.
(over phone) Yes?
I'm calling for details.
For what?
Details about the party.
Who is this?
I don't think we've met.
Well then I don't think you're invited to my party. It's a rather exclusive gathering.

I can imagine. (she starts to speak, he cuts her off) You should really work on your invite management. That might be a personal 'room for improvement' area in your life. But discretion of your invite sending aside, I have procured a certain someone's invitation, and would like details.
A beat of silence.
You think you're cute, whoever you are.
Wait'll you get a load of my felt fedora and spats.
Who are you? Or I'll hang up.
You don't know me - I'll save you some time.
I know everyone and I've got all the time in the world.
Folly of youth. Ask whose invitation I've got.
(slightly) What you said.
Emily Kostich.
A beat.
15 Bush street, up in Stockton Cove. Buzz 42 at the gate. Nine o'clock. But who-
Brendan hangs up. He folds his hands under his chin and stares at the phone, perfectly still. The clock on his de says 4:53.
7:37 Brendan at his desk, tapping away at Tetris.
8:30 The desk is empty, Tetris paused. A shower runs behind an ajar door in the background.

An imposing private community gate. Brendan coasts up on bike and ditches it in the bushes. He checks the call box directory: "42 -- DANNON" Using the call box as a hand hold he hops the gate and wa briskly up the street.
Shiny cars line the curb. Party noises come from an upsca two story house. Brendan takes a short breath, then strid up to the front door.

Large and clean, with a two story ceiling and a railed staircase at one end. Fifteen or twenty clean people, som in costumes, mill about in cliques. Brendan comes in as i he doesn't mind who sees him coming in. He gets a couple stares, but no one stops him. With non obtrusive confidence he cuts through the crowd t the beer keg in back and draws half a cup.

Richly adorned, crowded, lit with bright pools of light. Brendan drifts in and stands in the back, deep in shadow. The music comes from a baby grand piano set against one wall. Laura Dannon leans against it. She wears a red kimono, and is striking against the velvet black piano. Laura's kid sister, 11 years old with glasses, sits at th piano playing "All I do is Dream of You". Laura sings, lovely and soft but with strength.1 Brendan watches from the back, his face obscured in shado but his eyes gleam. Through the darkened window behind hi a match flares up, and someone standing outside lights a cigarette. Laura finishes the song. The room applauds, and she ruffl her kid sister's hair. Brendan ducks out, and into 1 By the time we got around to production this had changed Me," but the publishing rights proved too expensive (i.e. & Sullivan song, which besides being lovely was also in t
Brad Bramish, the jock who was kissing Laura in the parki lot, sits slouched on the couch in a dense crowd. He hold cup and speaks much too loudly to a guy named Biff at his elbow.

If the coach wants to play me I'll play, but I can't put my best game in if I've got to worry about whether I'm going to be in there. Halftime last game, coach is pissed I ran it on a pass play, out on the field he says to me 'you gotta think about the team and you gotta' you know and 'if you run that ball again you're out', and I said to him you gotta let me play! I'm out there, let me play, and he's saying 'no you're out' and I kept saying 'Let me play! Let me play! Let me play!', just right in his face-
He was!
Just 'Let me play! Let me play! Let me play!' 'No you gotta' 'No, let me play! Let me play! Let me play!'

Brad hunches forward, his face swollen purple, yelling th over and over. Tom steps in front of Brendan, blocking hi line of sight. Brendan scans the rest of the room. His eyes catch on Lau leaning against a divan. Her bright, sharp eyes cut throu the room, straight into Brendan. He wags his eyebrows at her. She looks away quickly. Brendan turns back to Brad, still shouting 'let me play'. Tom stands between them.
Tom!

Brad falls silent. Most of the room follows suit. Tom tur around. Brendan smiles good naturedly. BRENDAN (cont'd) Could you step aside, please? I'm trying to follow Brad's story, and it's difficult when I can't see his face.
The room watches Brendan. Tom mumbles something and steps aside. Brad stares at Brendan stupidly. Brendan flashes a dopey grin and tips his glass.
(stumbles) He doesn't give me a play to make, what can I do, you know?

He falls into awkward silence. Biff starts babbling. Brendan looks at Brad, who is staring back at him. Brendan then slowly drags his gaze over to Laura, staring him too, her eyes slightly amused. Brendan cocks an eyebr The slightest hint of a smile takes the corner of her mou and she wags her eyebrows once at him. Brendan glances back at Brad, looking at Laura now, not amused at all. Brendan stands to go. Biff chatters on. Brad cuts him off BRAD (cont'd) Hey. Hey! What are you doing here?
Leaving.
Oh yeah?
Uh huh. Unless your anecdote's got a 2nd act.
Why don't you leave?
(leaving) That's what I was doing.
With a lit wet bar at one end. Brendan goes to the bar, p ice in a glass and cracks it with liquor.
(O.S.) Whiskey?
Brendan pauses, glass touching his lips.
Jameson.
He downs half of it.
I like a man who knows what he's drinking.
That's a pretty sick thing to be attracted to.
Brad's not a good guy to get on the wrong side of.
Uh huh.
They stare at each other in silence. She studies his face The broken light of the bar makes her features seem liqui
Fearless flyer. Quit your yappin and fix me one.
and slips out a sliding glass door. He fills another glass with whiskey and cuts his with wat
Brendan joins Laura, hands her a drink. Suburban lights f the valley below. Laura sips her drink.
I'll never get through all this.
Uh huh.
She sips more.
I knew your old partner Jerr since grade school. Tough break. How long were you two joined up before your operation got the sting? BRENDAN
A few months. Could have helped himself out by turning me in, but he took the heat. He was a good guy. Solid. LAURA
Was he? BRENDAN
You knew him. LAURA
Yeah I did. So why are you here tonight? BRENDAN
I'm looking for Emily. LAURA
She wasn't invited. BRENDAN
She had an invitation. LAURA
Well like you said, I've got to work on that. Em's been AWOL for a good month, nobody's seen her. BRENDAN
I saw her yesterday. LAURA
Nearly nobody's seen her. So what did she tell you? BRENDAN
(winces) Score 0 for finesse. LAURA

Listen, you're scratching at the wrong door. I wasn't with Emily enough to know details of what she was in, I just got wind of the downfall, and I didn't get any details of that, except that it was bad. So now that we're showing some cards... BRENDAN
If you haven't got a finger in Em's troubles, why'd her name get me into your rather exclusive party?
Keep up with me now. I don't know, but it sounded like you did, and a body's got a right to be curious. Now I'm not so sure.
Well I'll put that body to bed. I don't know a damn thing about whatever troubles, and that works for me. I just want to find her.
A long beat. Laura studies Brendan's face, then seems to come to a decision.
Coffee and pie.
The words hang in the air a moment. A look of recognition from Brendan.
Coffee and pie oh my?
And you didn't hear it from me.

He sips his drink. A voice calls from the glass door. Another girl. Laura flashes Brendan a look and goes to he They have quick, quiet words and the girl leaves. Laura turns back to Brendan. LAURA (CONT'D) (cont'd) Will you wait here for me?
Sure.
You'll stay right here and wait -- I'll be five minutes.
Yes.
The moment she leaves Brendan runs across the lawn and ho the fence, into the neighbor's yard.

Brendan runs to the edge of the neighboring house and pee around. Laura comes out the front door, cuts across the lawn and sidewalk and trots out into the street. Brendan begins to follow, but a noise from behind the fence stops him - a match being struck. Brendan creeps towards the fence and peers through a splintered hole.

A brightly lit window in the side of Brad's house, and through the window the party. A dark figure wearing a long coat and broad rimmed hat, a inky black. The figure smokes a cigarette and watches the party, absently stroking his cheek. Brendan steps back - SNAP!   A twig. The figure freezes. Then, making no noise at all, it spin to face Brendan, a towering black form against the window The glowing cigarette falls to the grass. A metallic glint, and a clicking sound not unlike a gun. Brendan throws himself backwards onto the grass. A beat. Through the hole the black of the figure's cloak whips aw Brendan hesitates, then hops the fence.

Brendan lands on his feet. No black figure to be found. The cigarette still smolders on the ground. Hand rolled, plain paper. Brendan gazes through the window, catching his breath. Th he breaks the trance and creeps towards the street.
Peeking around the house, Brendan sees Laura cut across t lawn and trot into the street. Using parked cars as cover Brendan follows.

Between cars, Brendan sees a lanky kid in baggy jeans and engineer boots with a clean shaven head leaning against a black Mustang. Laura goes to him and speaks quickly. The dark figure in the hat emerges from the shadows. Laur says something to him. Grunting something angrily, he get in the car with the bald kid and peels off. Laura turns and slowly walks towards the house. When she is gone Brendan stands, throws a look back at th house and walks off down the street, towards the guard ga
The two drinks, where Brendan left them. Laura takes hers and drains it. The suburban lights twinkle like stars.

The sun rises over Carrows family restaurant, a squat structure backed against the weedy edge of the runoff tun ravine. A banner from 1973 in the window - "Coffee and Pie oh my! A pack of six pale stoners slump against the rear dumpste Their beady eyes follow Brendan in sync as he approaches. He goes to the nearest one.
Where's Dode?
Dunno, bra.
Silence and blank stares. Brendan calmly moves to the nex stoner.
Dode?
Uh uh.
Brendan moves to the next one. A thin head pokes from around the dumpster.
Hey Brendan. Maybe you shouldn't be here.
Brendan steps around the dumpster. Dode slumps against th wall, thin and delicate in dusty black. Slivery eyes, pal lips, muffled intelligence.
Kara told me you know where Em's at.
Uh huh.   And why are you looking for Em?
She asked for my help.
Uh huh. Listen man, I've got plenty on my plate without dealing with some jilted ex.
It's not about that.
Whatever it's about, act smarter than you look and drop it.
Where is she?
She's with me, and right now that's the best place for her. Leave the low life to the low lifers and dangle.
You're on the bright side of dim, Dode, but if I thought you had this half- handled I'd be eating lunch. Where's she at?
Better get while it's good.
Brendan doesn't. DODE (cont'd) Heel it now, dig?

The 5 big stoners appear behind Brendan, threatening.   D turns his head away to light a joint. Brendan's fist slams into his face, sending the joint spinning. Brendan slams Dode's frail frame against the dumpster. The 5 stoners stand in the exact same position, deer in t headlights. One makes a half hearted motion to intervene.
Back off.
Throw one at me if you want, hash head. I've got all five senses and I slept last night, that puts me six up on the lot of you.
Just easy-
Brendan slams Dode into the wall.
(to Dode) Where's Em?
(deliberate) She's with me. She was tight when she called you, man. Came to and freaked. She told me to shake you if you came by. Said you'd only make things worse.
Brendan covers how shaken he is by this statement fairly well. He drops Dode.
Put him down, man!
Deal with whatever this ain't about and drop it.
(to Brendan) Nothing more here, bra.
Tell Emily I want to see her. Tell her if she still wants my help or not that's her business, but I want to hear it straight from her.
She don't -
Brendan walks away.
Today. She knows where I eat lunch.
When Brendan is a safe distance away the biggest stoner shouts with conviction
And stay out, punk!
Brendan hides behind a tall clump of bushes. A moment later Dode hustles away from Carrows. Brendan follows.

The sun is rising as Brendan tails Dode through the twist suburban streets. Brendan takes cover as Dode stops by a white hatchback. A girl gets out of the car and embraces Dode. Her wrist i adorned with the same cheap plastic bracelets as the dead girl's arm. Dode speaks quickly to her, she nods and spea back. He hands her a slip of paper, which she tucks into brightly colored address book and slips in her jacket pocket. They embrace again, Dode walks off and the girl g in her car. Brendan stumbles after the car, but it is quickly gone. H watches it go, then follows Dode back towards school.
Dode slumps into the front door of the brown building. Brendan watches him from a distance, eyes thoughtful. Aft a beat he turns and walks off into the thickening crowds students.
Brendan eats lunch alone on a concrete wall beside a long empty utility road behind the school.

Reclining on the wall, reading "Lord of the Flies". He raises his eyes, and sits up suddenly. Off in the distance on the utility road a tiny figure approaches, stumbling. Brendan jumps and hits the ground running towards the figure. Meet the girl with cheap bracelets, the girl Dode spoke t the dead girl, Emily. He catches her just as she stumbles and falls and carries her into the shade of a covered hallway.
Emily and Brendan sit in silence. She is very pretty, but she looks bad. Too much makeup, not enough sleep. She sniffles, speaks to her shoes.
I must have sounded pretty crazy on the phone. Yesterday.

She taps her shoes together lightly, eyes fixed on them. EMILY (cont'd) It was dumb, I got paranoid over a really stupid thing. I was high, I went crazy for a little bit, but now you have to forget about it. Please. That's how you can help me now, forget about it.

She turns her weak eyes to Brendan for the first time. stare is unwavering, searching. She pushes on. EMILY (cont'd) Brendan, I know you're mad at all these people, cause you think I went away from you and went to them. But you've got to start seeing it as my decision, stop being angry because where I want to be at's different from where you wanna be at.
(angry) Who fed you that line, Em?
She looks back at her shoes.
And stop picking on Dode. He's a good guy.
The Carrows rat?
He's a good friend.
So what am I?

(strained anger) Yeah, what are you? Eating back here, not liking anybody, how are you judging anyone? I loved you alot but I couldn't stand it, I had to get with people. I couldn't heckle life with you, I had to see what was what.
A beat. She taps her clogs. One has a hole worn through t sole. Her face contorts, seizes up, and she is sobbing. EMILY (cont'd) I'm sorry Brendan.
She buries her face in his shoulder. He has a hard time speaking.
You've got to come back to me, Em.
No. No. Never. I'm sorry. Never. I can't love on your terms, Brendan. I can't do that, I'm not like you.
You're in a spot, I can get you out of it. Come back to me, and whatever heat follows you I'll deal with.
No. You're not hearing me, no. I don't want to be put away and protected. No. EMILY (cont'd) No.
Tell me about the trouble, the brick and the pin -

You gonna fix things like you did with Jerr? No. I came to say goodbye, for good. Whatever you have to do to let me go, do it. I'm gonna let you go, I've decided that. Make sure that, you've got to, promise you won't torture yourself, that you'll let me go.
She embraces him, enveloping him in her jacket. His face a frozen mask. EMILY (cont'd) Let me go.
As she pulls away he mechanically slips an address book f her jacket pocket. He watches her as she walks away.
Brendan sits in the back, flipping through the address bo The teacher drones on about the significance of the pig's head in "Lord of the Flies".1
Illegible scribbles, names, numbers, nothing that stops h search - then the note Dode gave her, a corner of loose-l paper which looks like this: Brendan studies the paper intently.
The Brain studies the paper. Busses pull into the parking lot behind them. Brendan is distant, lost in thought.
Hm. Do you know anything else about this?

1 Our one and only scene in a classroom was moved to Brenda a location change. The degree to which the lack of classr commented on has always bemused the author, who cannot fo remember a single interesting thing that happened in a cl
(shakes his head) Mm.
Slim pickings. Why'd you let Dode fly when he came back to whose-her-name, at the theater?

(shrugs dismissively) Kara. It's their turf, I couldn't hear them without being seen, and that would only biff their play. Best to know it's there, let it ride and see what comes of it. (touches the paper) But anyway.
Hm. Well, if this is what I think it is, it didn't come straight from Dode, less he's playing out of his league. (beat) I can only give you my best guess.
Yeah.

When the upper crust does shady deeds they do them in different spots around town. I know under the pier's one, down by the bike trails in the state park's another. There's alot of them. The pitch is they've got little symbols for each one, and that's how they tell each other the place, so word won't get around. So this might be that.
But Dode wouldn't know it?
This is upper crust. Dode's pie pan grease.
Brendan studies the symbol.
Call anything up?

How many places start with 'A'? Or if it's a shape, or just a random symbol. Anyway, even if you figured it out, what good could you do? She's smart, she knows the play, she's gunning to square things.
Yeah.
You said her business was none of yours, so she's alright, forget it now. Go home, sleep.
Sparsely furnished. Brendan plays Tetris on his computer, staring off into space. His mom's voice calls "Good night and the hallway light turns off.
10:30 by the clock radio on Brendan's nightstand. The sli of paper rests beside it. Brendan lies in bed, staring at the symbol on the paper. His eyes tense.

Growing larger, burning with a searing intensity, then folding into darkness. Water rushes overhead, over concre concrete with a hole in it -- the runoff tunnel, just for instant, then back underwater, screaming. Brendan choking screaming, plunging upwards. A woman with no face falls f the darkness and kisses him, her long hair sweeping aroun him then pulling away. As the last strands slide off his face he wakes up with a start. The clock says 3:46. Brendan drips with sweat, breathing raggedly. He takes the paper and a pencil from the nightstand and shades the symbol to look like this: FLASH CUT - The runoff tunnel, lining up perfectly with t now shaded symbol.
His eyes turn uneasy as he removes his glasses and clicks off the light.
Brendan walks off into the hazy pre-dawn light.
Brendan stops at a high wall of weeds, listening to the l gurgle of moving water. Slowly, robotically he pushes through.
Face down, bobbing gently in shallow water. Bluish white. Red foam clings to her.
Silently, as if lowered by a string Brendan sinks down, squatting in the mud. His lungs empty in one choppy breat He pulls his glasses off sluggishly.
Lifeless, pale.
A contorted, frozen mask, eyes wet.
Stringy, flowing gently in the water.

Dazed, drifting... then suddenly snapping to attention. A noise. From the tunnel. Brendan freezes. The inky blackness of the tunnel mouth opens like a vacuum... silent, but then - The scrape of a shoe against concrete, then echoing footsteps running away. Brendan springs like a cat, sprinting into the tunnel.

Nearly pitch black. 2 sets of running footfalls. Brendan chasing, running full speed into the blackness, heart pounding - we almost don't notice that Brendan's are now only footfalls. Brendan notices. He stops. Silence in the darkness, excep for Brendan's breath... and someone near... SLAM! Brendan takes a fist in the cheek and goes down. An inky black figure steps from the shadows and kicks him in the stomach. Brendan curls on the ground, the figure over him.
(low whisper) Your little Em.
The figure runs off. Brendan raises his head painfully - figure is silhouetted briefly against the distant bright of the tunnel, then is gone.
Emily's body is still there. Brendan crawls out of the tunnel and collapses in the shallow water, beside the bod He rests his head on his arm, eyes on Em's hair.
Cold and barren, nearly empty. Brendan limps across the barren lawns.
A line of phone booths on campus. Brendan nearly collapse against one. He dials, still in a stupor.
Saint Clement police.
Brendan stares into space, eyes burning VOICE ON PHONE (cont'd) Saint Clement police, hello? Hello?
Brendan hangs up.
Early morning mist below a squat brick building.
Warmly lit, sheltering the few souls scattered here and there at tables. The Brain sits at one of them reading an impossibly large book. He watches curiously as Brendan approaches him.
Hey, Brendan.
Brendan falls into a chair. The Brain looks him over. THE BRAIN (cont'd) You're up early.
(thick, distant) I couldn't sleep.
(nods, back to his book) Find Emily?
Brendan breathes out softly. THE BRAIN (cont'd) You alright?
Yeah. What, are you here for zero?
Nah, I gotta take the early bus, cause the others don't run by my street.
Bad break.
Eh. Time to read's nice. So what's the word with Em?
She's gone.
Can't raise her?
No, I can't.
So what now?
Now. I don't know. I guess it's... I don't know.
